parts.str: The intake survey focuses on some background and demographic information.
For whom are you filling in this survey?
To find out whether the chance of getting COVID-19 or flu are different between men and women.
What is your date of birth (month and year)?
The chance of getting COVID-19 and the risk of more serious complications vary by age.
What is the first part of your home postcode (the part before the space)?
To check how representative our sample is, and to see whether the chance of getting flu varies across the country.
Please choose the first part of the post-code (the part before the space).
Please enter the first part of your postal code
To check how representative our sample is compared to the population as a whole, and to find out whether the chance of getting flu is different for people in different types of occupation.
Please, tick the box that most closely resembles your main occupation. For pre-school children who don't go to daycare tick the "other" box.
If applicable what is the first part of your postcode where you spend most of your time other than home (for example work, school/university)?
To check how representative our sample is, and to see whether the chance of getting flu varies across the country.
Please choose the first part of the post-code (the part before the space).
the first part of the postcode
Please enter the first part of the postal code of your work/school/university
What is the highest level of formal education/qualification that you have?
To check how representative our sample is compared to the population of the UK (Italy, Belgium..) as a whole.

Please choose the box that represents your HIGHEST level of educational achievements. The different option rougly equate to: 1 - no qualifications, 2 - school-leaving exams at around 16 years of age, 3 - school-leaving exams at around 18 years of age, 4 - University degree or equivalent professional qualification, 5 - Higher degree or advanced professional qualification. If you are an adult who is currently undergoing part - time training(e.g.night school) then tick the box that represents your current highest level of education.
A-levels or equivalent (e.g. Higher, NVQ Level3, BTEC)
Higher Degree or equivalent (e.g. Masters Degree, PGCE, PhD, Medical Doctorate, Advanced Professional Award)
Except people you meet on public transports, do you have contact with any of the following during the course of a typical day (so without covid measures)?
To find out whether you are likely to be exposed to more infection risk than the average person (e.g. work with children, or patients).
Groups of people could include any setting where you come into contact with large numbers of people at once, e.g. a teacher who may contact many children in a day.
Groups of people (more than 10 individuals at any one time)
INCLUDING YOU, how many people in each of the following age groups live in your household?
How many of the children in your household go to school or day-care?
What is your main means of transport?
Please select the transportation means you use the most.
On a normal day, how much time do you spend on public transport? (Bus, train, tube etc.)
It has been suggested that using public transport may be a risk for getting flu. We would like to check this.
Think of a typical day. If you use several different forms of public transport each day, remember to include all journeys. Don't include taxis or other forms of private transport.
Did you receive a flu vaccine during the last autumn/winter season? (2022/2023)
We would like to be able to work out how much protection the vaccine gives. We would also like to find out if there is some protection from vaccines received in previous years.
Report yes, if you received the vaccine this season, usually in the autumn.
Are you planning to receive a flu vaccine this autumn/winter season? (2023/2024)
Report yes, if you received the vaccine this season, usually in the autumn.
Report yes, if you received the vaccine this season, usually in the autumn. If you get vaccinated after filling in this questionnaire, please return to this and update your answer.
When were you vaccinated against flu in the season 2023/2024?
What were your reasons for getting a seasonal influenza vaccination this year?
I belong to a risk group (e.g, pregnant, over 65, underlying health condition, etc)
Vaccination decreases my risk of getting influenza
Vaccination decreases the risk of spreading influenza to others
It was recommended in my workplace/school
The vaccine was readily available and vaccine administration was convenient
I don't want to miss work/school
I try to protect myself against infections, because of the circulation of the coronavirus
What were your reasons for NOT getting a seasonal influenza vaccination in seaseon 2023/2024?
We would like to know why some people get vaccinated and others do not.
Tick all those reasons that were important in your decision.
I don't belong to a risk group
It is better to build your own natural immunity against influenza
I doubt that the influenza vaccine is effective
I don't think I am likely to get influenza
I believe that influenza vaccine can cause influenza
I am worried that the vaccine is not safe or will cause illness or other adverse events
The vaccine is not readily available to me
The vaccine is not free of charge
Although my doctor recommend a vaccine, I do not get one
Have you ever received a COVID-19 vaccine (since December 2020)?
Are you planning to receive a COVID-19 vaccine this season (2023-2024)?
Do you take regular medication for any of the following medical conditions?
This question allows us to find out whether you have other medical conditions that may increase your risk of having more severe illness if you are infected.
Only answer "yes" if you take regular medication for your medical problem. If, for instance, you only occasionally take an asthma inhaler, then do not answer "yes" for asthma.
Chronic lung disorder besides asthma e.g. COPD, emphysema, or other disorders that affect your breathing
An immunocompromising condition (e.g. splenectomy, organ transplant, acquired immune deficiency, cancer treatment)
Infections during pregnancy can be different.
Which trimester of the pregnancy are you in?
The stage of pregnancy might alter your infection, although this is not very clear.
Yes, daily, fewer than 10 times a day
Yes, daily, 10 or more times a day
Do you have one of the following allergies that can cause respiratory symptoms?
Some allergic reactions can have similar symptoms to respiratory infections.
Tick all the options that apply. We are only interested in those allergies that cause respiratory symptoms (i.e. sneezing, sunny nose, runny eyes).
Allergy against domestic animals or pets
Other allergies that cause respiratory symptoms (e.g. sneezing, runny eyes)
I do not have an allergy that causes respiratory symptoms
How often do you have common colds or flu-like diseases?
Do you have pets at home?
Yes, one ore more other animals
Where did you first hear about the flusurvey?
In the newspaper or in a magazine
UKHSA website (or a search engine or link)
We’re considering including self-swabbing (nose and throat) as part of the survey. If this was offered, might you be interested in taking part.
This was all for now, please submit your responses. Please come back and find a different survey about how you feel and your health status.
